    • Moult data likelihoods and model priors

    Moult data likelihoods and model priors

    moult-likelihoods.Rmd

    The moultmcmc package implements the regression models outlined in Les G. Underhill and Zucchini (1988) and L. G. Underhill, Zucchini, and Summers (1990). In their notation1, samples consist of II pre-moult birds, JJ birds in active moult, and KK post-moult birds. Birds in each category are observed on days t=t1,…,tIt = t_1,\ldots,t_I; u=u1,…,uJu = u_1,\ldots,u_J; v=v1,…,vKv = v_1,\ldots,v_K, respectively. Moult scores for actively moulting birds, where available, are encoded as y=y1,…,yJy = y_1,\ldots,y_J.

    Each moult state has a probability of occurrence P(t)=Pr{Y(t)=0}=1−FT(t)Q(t)=Pr{0<Y(t)<1}=FT(t)−FT(t−τ)R(t)=Pr{Y(t)=1}=1−FT(t−τ) \begin{aligned} P(t) &= \Pr\{Y(t)=0\}&= &1-F_T(t)\\ Q(t) &= \Pr\{0<Y(t)<1\}& =&F_T(t)-F_T(t-\tau)\\ R(t) &= \Pr\{Y(t)=1\}&= &1-F_T(t-\tau)\\ \end{aligned} Further, assuming a linear progression of the moult indices over time, the probability density of a particular moult score at time tt is fY(t)(y)=τfT(t−yτ),0<y<1, f_Y(t)(y)=\tau f_T(t-y\tau),\quad0 < y < 1, In moultmcmc the unobserved start date of the study population is assumed to follow a normal distribution with mean μ\mu and standard deviation σ\sigma, such that FT(t)=Φ(t−μσ)F_T(t)=\Phi\left(\frac{t-\mu}{\sigma}\right) where Φ\Phi is the standard normal distribution function and fT(t)=ϕ(t)=12πexp−t22f_T(t) = \phi(t) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp\frac{-t^2}{2}.

    We further assume that FT(t)F_T(t) has pp parameters 𝛉=θ1,θ2,…,θp\mathbf{\theta} = \theta_1, \theta_2, \ldots, \theta_p and for convenience the start date μ\mu, duration τ\tau, and population standard deviation of moult σ\sigma will be elements of 𝛉\mathbf{\theta}.

    Likelihoods

    Type 1

    Type 1 data consist of observations of categorical moult state (pre-moult, active moult, post-moult) and sampling is representative in all three categories. The likelihood of these observations is ℒ(𝛉,t,u,v)=∏i=1IP(ti)∏j=1JQ(uj)∏k=1KR(vk). \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,t,u,v) = \prod_{i=1}^IP(t_i)\prod_{j = 1}^JQ(u_j)\prod_{k=1}^KR(v_k).

    Type 2

    Type 2 data consist of observations of birds in all three moult states (pre-moult, active moult, post-moult). Sampling is representative for all three categories, and for actively moulting birds a sufficiently linear moult index yy (e.g. percent feather mass grown) is known. The likelihood of these observations is ℒ(𝛉,t,u,y,v)=∏i=1IP(ti)∏j=1Jq(uj,yj)∏k=1KR(vk), \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,t,u,y,v) = \prod_{i=1}^IP(t_i)\prod_{j = 1}^Jq(u_j,y_j)\prod_{k=1}^KR(v_k), where q(uj,yj)=τfT(uj−yjτ).q(u_j,y_j) = \tau f_T(u_j-y_j\tau).

    Lumped Type 2

    Lumped type 2 data consist of observations of birds in all three moult states (pre-moult, active moult, post-moult), but where the pre-moult and post-moult states cannot be distinguished from each other, yielding II observations of dates tit_i on which non-moulting birds were observed. Sampling is representative for all three categories, and for actively moulting birds a sufficiently linear moult index yy (e.g. percent feather mass grown) is known. The likelihood of these observations is ℒ(𝛉,t,u,y)=∏i=1IPR(ti)∏j=1Jq(uj,yj), \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,t,u,y) = \prod_{i=1}^IPR(t_i)\prod_{j = 1}^Jq(u_j,y_j), where q(uj,yj)=τfT(uj−yjτ)q(u_j,y_j) = \tau f_T(u_j-y_j\tau) and PR(ti)=P(ti)+R(ti).PR(t_i)=P(t_i)+R(t_i).

    Type 3

    Type 3 data consist of observations of actively moulting birds only, and a sufficiently linear moult index yy (e.g. percent feather mass grown) is known for each individual. The likelihood of these observations is ℒ(𝛉,u,y)=∏j=1Jq(uj,yj)Q(uj). \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,u,y) = \prod_{j = 1}^J\frac{q(u_j,y_j)}{Q(u_j)}.

    Type 4

    Type 4 data consist of observations of birds in active moult and post-moult only. Sampling is representative for these two categories, and for actively moulting birds a sufficiently linear moult index yy (e.g. percent feather mass grown) is known. The likelihood of these observations is ℒ(𝛉,u,y,v)=∏j=1Jq(uj,yj)1−P(uj)∏k=1KR(vk)1−P(vk). \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,u,y,v) = \prod_{j = 1}^J\frac{q(u_j,y_j)}{1-P(u_j)}\prod_{k=1}^K\frac{R(v_k)}{1-P(v_k)}.

    Type 5

    Type 5 data consist of observations of birds in pre-moult and active moult. Sampling is representative for these two categories, and for actively moulting birds a sufficiently linear moult index yy (e.g. percent feather mass grown) is known. The likelihood of these observations is ℒ(𝛉,t,u,y)=∏i=1IP(ti)1−R(ti)∏j=1Jq(uj,yj)1−R(uj). \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,t,u,y) = \prod_{i=1}^I\frac{P(t_i)}{1-R(t_i)}\prod_{j = 1}^J\frac{q(u_j,y_j)}{1-R(u_j)}.

    Type 1 + 2

    As outlined in Les G. Underhill and Zucchini (1988) estimates can also be derived from mixtures of data types. Type 1 + 2 data consist of observations of birds in all three moult states (pre-moult, active moult, post-moult). Sampling is representative for all three categories, but a sufficiently linear moult index yy (e.g. percent feather mass grown) is known only for some of the actively moulting birds. This means the sample consist of II pre-moult birds, JJ birds in active moult with known indices, LL birds in active moult without known indices but known capture dates u′=u′l,…,u′Lu'=u'_l,\ldots,u'_L, and KK post-moult birds. The likelihood of these observations is ℒ(𝛉,t,u,y,u′,v)=∏i=1IP(ti)∏j=1Jq(uj,yj)∏l=1LQ(u′l)∏k=1KR(vk), \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,t,u,y,u',v) = \prod_{i=1}^IP(t_i)\prod_{j = 1}^Jq(u_j,y_j)\prod_{l = 1}^{L}Q(u'_{l})\prod_{k=1}^KR(v_k),

    Recapture models

    moultmcmc currently implements a recaptures model which allows for heterogeneity in start dates μ\mu but assumes a common moult duration τ\tau. When repeat observations are available an individual’s start date μn\mu_n then becomes

    μn=μ0+μ′n+𝐱μ𝛃μ\begin{equation} \mu_n = \mu_0 + \mu'_n + \mathbf{x}_\mu\boldsymbol{\beta}_\mu \end{equation}

    where 𝐱μ\boldsymbol{x}_\mu is a row vector containing the values of individual-specific predictors (in the same format as 𝐗μ\boldsymbol{X}_\mu), and μ′n\mu'_n is an individual-level random effect intercept

    μ′n∼Normal(0,σn)\begin{equation} \mu'_n \sim \mathrm{Normal}(0,\sigma_n) \end{equation} where σn\sigma_n is the individual-specific standard deviation. We can then exploit the linearity assumption and treat observed moult scores as yni∼Normal(μ0+μ′n+τ*uni,στ)\begin{equation} y_{ni} \sim \mathrm{Normal}(\mu_0 + \mu'_n + \tau * u_{ni}, \sigma_\tau) \end{equation} where στ\sigma_\tau captures any unmodelled variance in τ\tau as well as any measurement error in yy.

    The likelihood for the Type 3-like model for a sample of JJ birds in active moult without repeated observations, and NN birds in active moult with a total of MM repeated observations u′=u′m,…,u′Mu'=u'_m,\ldots,u'_M and y′=y′m,…,y′My'=y'_m,\ldots,y'_M then is

    ℒ(𝛉,u,y,u′,y′)=∏j=1Jq(uj,yj)Q(uj)∏m=1Mf(u′m,y′m)∏n=1Nϕ(μ′n|0,σn), \mathcal{L}(\boldsymbol\theta,u,y,u',y') = \prod_{j = 1}^J\frac{q(u_j,y_j)}{Q(u_j)}\prod_{m = 1}^{M}f(u'_m,y'_m)\prod_{n=1}^N\phi(\mu'_n|0,\sigma_n), where f(u′m,y′m)f(u'_m,y'_m) follows from above.

    Priors

    Users have a choice between two set of priors for the intercept terms of the linear predictors on the start date μ\mu, the duration τ\tau, and the population standard deviation of the start date σ\sigma, respectively. By default flat priors are used for μ0\mu_0 and τ0\tau_0 and a vaguely informative normal prior on ln(σ0)\ln(\sigma_0)

    μ0∼Uniform(0,366)\mu_0 \sim \mathrm{Uniform(0,366)}
    τ0∼Uniform(0,366)\tau_0 \sim \mathrm{Uniform(0,366)}
    ln(σ0)∼Normal(0,5)\ln(\sigma_0) \sim \mathrm{Normal(0,5)}

    In some cases the models sample poorly with these priors, and better convergence can be achieved by setting the argument flat_prior = FALSE. In this case vaguely informative truncated normal priors are used for μ0\mu_0 and τ0\tau_0:

    μ0∼TruncNormal(150,50,0,366)\mu_0 \sim \mathrm{TruncNormal(150,50,0,366)}
    τ0∼TruncNormal(100,30,0,366)\tau_0 \sim \mathrm{TruncNormal(100,30,0,366)}

    These priors work well for data from passerines in seasonal environments, i.e. when the sampling occasion data is encoded as days from mid-winter.

    For any additional regression coefficients an improper flat prior is used as a default.

    References

    Underhill, L. G., W. Zucchini, and R. W. Summers. 1990. “A Model for Avian Primary Moult-Data Types Based on Migration Strategies and an Example Using the Redshank Tringa Totanus.” Ibis 132: 118–23. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1474-919x.1990.tb01024.x.
    Underhill, Les G., and Walter Zucchini. 1988. “A Model for Avian Primary Moult.” Ibis 130: 358–72. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1474-919x.1988.tb00993.x.

    1. Note that in Les G. Underhill and Zucchini (1988) the variable tt is doubly defined. It is both a generic variable of time in the model derivation, and denotes the sample dates of pre-moult birds in the data likelihoods↩︎
